data.name: Guide_TestExecution_intro_Content
data.value:
This guide will help you quickly understand how to execute your tests in ValidationMaster.

Let's walk through the main interface elements before seeing how to actually execute tests.

Click 'next' below to continue.

data.name: Guide_TestExecution_heading_Content
data.value: This shows the name of the test run (if present) and the selected release.

data.name: Guide_TestExecution_display_Content
data.value:
There are three different display modes.
Each has two display options.

They are designed for different ways of working

data.name: Guide_TestExecution_settings_Content
data.value: Click here to access settings for how you want the page set up, or to replay this tour.

data.name: Guide_TestExecution_progress_Content
data.value: Use this to check on progress through the tests (it shows test steps by default, test cases if there are many test steps). You can see information about the test on hover.

data.name: Guide_TestExecution_moving_Content
data.value: Click here to move back or forward one test. Or click any test in the progress bar, or in the list below to go straight there.

data.name: Guide_TestExecution_pause_Content
data.value: If you need to step away from a test run, click the pause button to stop the internal timer for the test. It glows when paused to remind you to start the timer when you resume testing.

data.name: Guide_TestExecution_exit_Content
data.value: Click here to exit testing. The unfinished test can be found on 'My Page'. When the test can be finished, an orange button will appear just to the right.

data.name: Guide_TestExecution_split_Content
data.value:
This lets you see a list of all the steps next to an inspector which shows detailed information about the current test step.

Use the tabs at the bottom to view additional information.

Display Options: make the inspector wide or narrow to suit your needs

data.name: Guide_TestExecution_table_Content
data.value:
This display mode is great for showing you all of your steps together. It is designed to let you very quickly review and take action on each step.

Display Options: collapse or expand all fields in the table at once to manage what is shown on screen. Note that every field can be collapsed or expanded individually too.

data.name: Guide_TestExecution_mini_Content
data.value:
The main view shows a full screen inspector. It maximizes the space dedicated to showing you information about the current step.

Display Options: let you switch from inspector only to inspector with an iframe. This lets you test a webpage with the test information right next to it.

data.name: Guide_TestExecution_status_Content
data.value:
You can log the status of a step in any view. You may be prompted to enter an "Actual Result" (e.g. if you are failing the step).

Note: to add a result manually in the table view, click on the "+" button for that step.
You may be required to create an Incident at this time too.

data.name: Guide_TestExecution_screenshot_Content
data.value:
Paste the image directly into the 'Actual Result' text editor.

This will upload and save the image, and make sure the image is properly referenced in the textbox as well.

data.name: Guide_TestExecutionExploratory_intro_Content
data.value:
This guide will briefly show you how to execute test cases in ValidationMaster using its exploratory testing mode.

This is designed for experienced testers. This guide assumes you are already familiar with how standard test execution works in ValidationMaster.

Click 'next' below to continue.

data.name: Guide_TestExecutionExploratory_editing_Content
data.value:
When you execute tests in exploratory mode, you can edit most parts of the test. Simply click on a field and start typing.

You can change the name of the test run, the description, and many other fields. When a field is grayed out, you won't be able to edit it.

As soon as you move to another field, the changes you make are immediately saved on the server --note that the underlying test case is NOT changed at all (you can choose later whether to change the test case or not).

data.name: Guide_TestExecutionExploratory_grid_Content
data.value:
Just like with normal test execution, clicking on any test step will let you work on that step. The details are shown in the inspector on the right.
If any step is grayed out, it means that you do not have permission to edit that step, but you can still record results for that step.

A step cannot be edited when it originates from a linked test case.

data.name: Guide_TestExecutionExploratory_gridStep_Content
data.value:
If you hover over any step (that's not grayed out) you will see three horizontal dots on the right hand side of the step.
Clicking on this bring ups a mini action menu. This lets you either clone this step, or delete it.

If you clone the step a duplicate is created and put at the bottom of the list of steps. If you delete the step, it will be removed from this run.

data.name: Guide_TestExecutionExploratory_gridStepMoving_Content
data.value:
You can click and hold on any step and then drag it up or down the list to place it in a new position. This is a really easy way to reorder your test steps.

You can do this at any time: none of the information in the step will be changed in any way.

data.name: Guide_TestExecutionExploratory_gridAdd_Content
data.value:
To add a new step, click this button. A blank step will be created and placed at the bottom of the list of test steps. It can then be fully edited in the same way as other steps.

Combined with functionality already mentioned, this gives you a lot of power to design and change your test run as you explore the functionality you are testing.

data.name: Guide_TestExecutionExploratory_tasks_Content
data.value:
While exploring, you may well find something a developer should look at. You may be uncertain if this is a bug or the testing may be during early stages of development. In each of these cases, creating an incident may be too formal an action.

Instead, why not create a task? You can add a title, an optional description, and assign the task to a colleague in a few seconds.

You can see all the tasks created for this test run at any time.

data.name: Guide_TestExecutionExploratory_settings_Content
data.value:
There are a number of ways your exploratory testing workspace can be customized. Specifically, various fields can be set on a per user basis to show or hide. For example, if you don't use "Sample Data" during your exploratory tests, then you can hide that field.

You can optionally show the last results for a step (if it exists) so you can quickly compare it with the current results.

data.name: Guide_TestExecutionExploratory_exit_Content
data.value:
Once the exploratory testing is complete a button will appear here in orange with a "stop" symbol. Clicking this will show a dropdown with two options.

1. You can update the underlying test case based on all the changes you have made (editing, adding, deleting, moving steps).

2. Or you can leave the test case unchanged. If you select this option, only the execution status of the test case is updated. Note that the test run created from this session will fully reflect all the changes made on this page.

data.name: TestConfigurationDetails_ConfirmPopulation

data.name: AssociationPanel_CreateArtifactXFromArtifactYTooltip

data.name: AssociationPanel_ArtifactXCreatedFromArtifactY
data.value: A new {0} was successfully created from this {1}.

data.name: AssociationPanel_NoArtifactTypesCanBeAdded
data.value: You cannot add any associations to this artifact!

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_IncidentAging
data.value: This chart shows how long incidents have been left open: the age intervals are on the x-axis, the count of incidents on the y-axis.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_IncidentOpenCount
data.value: This chart shows the breakdown of all open incidents in the product by priority. The chart’s bar match the color assigned to that priority.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_IncidentTestCoverage
data.value: This chart shows the execution status of any test cases that previously failed and resulted in the generation of an incident that has subsequently been resolved. It can be very helpful to see which test cases likely need to be tested again, now that their incidents are resolved.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_RequirementGraphs
data.value: You can quickly view four different charts used when measuring the progress of requirements in an agile methodology: select the appropriate chart from the dropdown

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_RequirementsCoverage
data.value: This chart shows the aggregated count of requirements test coverage for the product. Each requirement's test coverage is summed to 1, to make requirements with different numbers of test cases covering them equally weighted. Filtering by release will filter requirements mapped to that release.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_RequirementsCoverageRegression
data.value: This chart shows the aggregated count of requirements test coverage for the product. Each requirement's test coverage is summed to 1, to make requirements with different numbers of test cases covering them equally weighted. Filtering by release will filter test cases, not requirements.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_SourceCodeCommits
data.value: This chart shows the last 3 months of code commits to the product (if you are using the source code functionality of the application). Commits are aggregated by week. The chart is color coded by bottom quartile, the middle 50%, and the top quartile of activity.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_TaskGraphs
data.value: You can quickly view three different charts used when measuring task progress in an agile methodology: select the appropriate chart from the dropdown

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_TestCasesPerStatusAndDay
data.value: This chart displays the last 30 days of test case executions cumulatively. That means it will display for each day, the total number of test cases executed plus the status from any previous days that have not been changed. Any test cases not executed up to that point will be considered “not run” and will appear in the “not run” category. For example, if you have 10 test cases created on day 1 you will see 10 test cases “not run” on day 1. On day 2, you execute 5 test cases and fail them all, you will now see 5 test cases failed and 5 not run. On day 3, you execute 3 of the previous 5 test cases and pass them. You will now see 3 test cases passed, 2 failed and 5 not run.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_TestExecutionStatus
data.value: This chart shows the aggregated count of test cases in each execution status for the product.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_TestRunProgress
data.value: This chart displays the last 30 days of test run activity broken down, for each day, by the test run status.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_TestSetStatus
data.value: This chart shows the aggregated count of test cases in each execution status for each test set in the product. If you have the same test cases in multiple test sets they are all counted separately to make sure you can tell that tests have passed successfully across test sets. This is helpful when testing across different environments.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_RequirementsCoverageProgram
data.value: This chart shows the aggregated count of requirements test coverage for the entire program. The Passed, Failed, Blocked, Caution and Not-Run bars indicate the total count of requirements that have tests covering them, allocated across the execution status of the covering tests.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_TaskProgress
data.value: This chart shows the aggregated count of tasks by progress category for the entire program. The ‘On Schedule’, ‘Late Finish’, ‘Late Start’ and ‘Not Started’ bars indicate the total count of tasks that are in that category for all the products in the program.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_TestExecutionStatusProgram
data.value: This chart shows the aggregated count of test cases by execution status for the entire program. The Passed, Failed, Blocked, Caution and Not-Run bars indicate the total count of test cases that are in that category for all the products in the program.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_DateRangeIncident
data.value:
The incident progress rate chart displays the total number of incidents created and closed over a particular date-range, either for all incident types or for a specific incident type

The cumulative incident count chart displays the cumulative total number of incidents logged over a particular date-range, either for all incident types or for a specific incident type. The report displays the total count of all incidents, and the total count of all open incidents (i.e. with status not set to fixed or closed)

The open incident count chart displays the net number of open incidents over a particular date-range categorized by incident priority, either for all incident types or for a specific incident type. For this chart, “open” is defined as any incident with an empty “Closed On” date. The incident status is not used for this chart.

The incident count by status displays the number of open incidents in the system for the current product over a particular date-range categorized by incident status, either for all incident types or for a specific incident type. For this chart, “open” is defined as any incident with an empty “Closed On” date. The incident status is not used for this chart.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_DateRangeTestRun
data.value:
The Test Run Progress Rate Graph shows how many tests have been executed for the selected release/sprint for a specific date range, and what execution status was recorded. The graph can be displayed for all test case types or for a specific type.

The Test Case Progress Rate Graph displays the number of test case executions for the specified date range, against the specified release/sprint, ignoring the status from any previous days. Any test cases not executed that day will be considered "not run" and will appear in the "not run" category.

The Test Case Cumulative Progress Graph displays the number of test case executions cumulatively over the specified date range, against the specified release/sprint. That means it will display for each day, the total number of test cases executed plus the status from any previous days that have not been changed. Any test cases not executed up to that point will be considered "not run" and will appear in the "not run" category.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_SnapshotIncident
data.value:
The incident aging graph displays the number of days incidents have been left open in the system with the count of incidents on the y-axis and different age intervals on the x-axis. Each bar-chart color represents a different incident priority, giving a product manager a snapshot view of the age of open incidents by priority and detected release. For this chart, "open" is defined as any incident with an empty "Closed On" date. The incident status is not used for this chart.

The incident turnaround time graph displays the number of days incidents have taken to be closed (from the time they were first raised) in the system with the count of incidents on the y-axis and different turnaround time intervals on the x-axis. Each bar-chart color represents a different incident priority, giving a product manager a snapshot view of the turnaround time of incidents by priority and detected release. For this chart, "closed" is defined as any incident with a "Closed On" date. The incident status is not used for this chart.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_SnapshotRequirement
data.value:
The requirements coverage graph shows how many requirements are currently in a product, according to their test coverage status

The Requirements Burndown graph shows the remaining number of story points that need to be completed for each release/sprint in the product with separate lines for the estimated and ideal burndown. In addition, the graph includes bars for the completed number of story points in each time period on the x-axis

The Requirements Burnup graph shows the cumulative number of story points outstanding for each release/sprint in the product with separate lines for the estimated and ideal burnup. In addition, the graph includes bars for the number of completed story points in each time period on the x-axis

The Requirements Velocity graph shows the total number of story points that have been completed (or planned to be completed) in a particular release, sprint or time-period (called the velocity). The actual velocity is displayed along with the overall average velocity (in blue) and the rolling average velocity (in green)

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_SnapshotTask
data.value:
The Task Velocity graph shows the total estimated and actual effort (in number of hours) delivered in each product release and/or sprint.

The Task Burnup graph shows the cumulative amount of work outstanding for each release/sprint in the product with separate lines for the estimated and ideal burnup. In addition, the graph includes bars for the remaining and completed effort in each time period on the x-axis.

The Task Burndown graph shows the remaining work (in hours) that needs to be done for each release/sprint in the product with separate lines for the estimated and ideal burndown. In addition, the graph includes bars for the remaining and completed effort in each time period on the x-axis.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_SummaryIncident
data.value: The incident summary graph shows how many incidents are currently in a product. The number of incidents is displayed according to the criteria that you specify.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_SummaryRequirement
data.value: The requirements summary graph shows how many requirements are currently in a product. The number of requirements is displayed according to the criteria that you specify

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_SummaryTask
data.value: The task summary graph shows how many tasks are currently in a product. The number of tasks is displayed according to the criteria that you specify.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_SummaryTestCase
data.value: The test case summary graph shows how many test cases are currently in a product. The number of test cases is displayed according to the criteria that you specify.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_SummaryTestRun
data.value: The test run summary graph shows how many test runs are currently in a product. The number of test runs is displayed according to the criteria that you specify.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_SummaryTestSet
data.value: The test set summary graph shows how many test set are currently in a product. The number of test sets is displayed according to the criteria that you specify

data.name: JqPlot_ImageExportNotSupport
data.value: Your web browser does not support image export!

data.name: DocumentDetails_DeleteVersionConfirm
data.value: Are you sure you want to delete this version of the document?

data.name: FileUpload_AttachmentEmpty
data.value: You cannot upload an empty attachment!

data.name: FileUpload_AttachmentTooLarge
data.value: You cannot upload an attachment larger than {0}KB!

data.name: FileUpload_VersionNumberRequired
data.value: You need to provide a version number!

data.name: FileUpload_VersionNumberTooLong
data.value: Your version number is too long!

data.name: Graphs_NeedToHaveASingleDataSeries
data.value: This graph type only supports a single data series!

data.name: RequirementDetails_SplitRequirementEstimateNotNumeric
data.value: The Estimate value needs to be numeric!

data.name: RequirementDetails_SplitRequirementNameRequired
data.value: You need to enter a Name for the new Requirement!

data.name: AjaxFormManager_NotAuthorizedToCreate
data.value: You are not authorized to create this item!

data.name: GlobalNavigation_SearchTooltip
data.value: You can search by keywords or by entering an artifact unique token (e.g. IN45 for incident 45)

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipArtifacts
data.value: Artifacts are the building blocks of a product or program and contain all of their data. Each artifact holds different data and is used in different ways. For instance, requirements are one artifact, and releases are another. They work differently, and are not interchangable. There are artifacts to help you test, plan, track bugs and tasks, and more.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipAutomationHost
data.value: Automation Hosts are all the different systems (ie testing machines) used to run automated tests in the product.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipTestConfigurationSet
data.value: A Configuration is a matrix of parameters that tests (both manual and automated) can be run against. Configurations let you quickly create every possible combination from multiple different parameters.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipDocument
data.value: All attachments, documents, images (including screenshots) and other files connected to the product are all visible here, with built-in versioning.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipIncident
data.value: All incidents in the product, including bugs, enhancements, risks, or any other type as specified by the product owner.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipMyPage
data.value: Your homepage contains all the information relevant to you—consolidated onto a single page for you to take immediate action

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipPlanningBoard
data.value: Visualize and manage backlog items planned for your product. This planning tool is based on Scrum and Kanban methodologies.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipRelease
data.value: Hierarchical collection of a product releases (including sprints and epics)

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipReporting
data.value: Generate a wide variety of charts and reports for the current workspace, including user generated reports. Reports can be filtered, sorted, and exported.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipRequirement
data.value: Hierarchical collection of requirements of any type, including user stories, use cases, and features

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipResource
data.value: Resource management to view every active member of a product, along with the total workload (both completed and planned).

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipSourceCode
data.value: View all files stored in the source code for this product across all current branches, and explore each files history.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipRevision
data.value: View the commit history for all of the product's source code and explore the specific changes made in each commit.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipTask
data.value: Tasks help break down larger areas of work like Requirements or Incidents, so discreet parts can be done by different people. Tasks can also be standalone activities.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipTestCase
data.value: Test Cases are the key unit of testing in the application. Each Test Case is made up of Test Steps. The execution status of a Test Case (eg pass or fail) can be traced across the system to Releases and Requirements.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipTestRun
data.value: Each time a Test Case is executed it creates a Test Run. Every execution in a product is collected as Test Runs that act as records for all testing activity.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipTestSet
data.value: Test Sets contain Test Cases. A Test Set acts as a store for dynamic testing data and for setting a specific order of execution of Test Cases.Test Sets are not folders: a Test Case can live in many Test Sets and even be in one Test Set multiple times.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipWorkspace
data.value: To start getting things done in the application you need to select a workspace to explore, manage, or work on. Workspaces can be products (e.g. for a specific application), programs (that group a number of products together), portfolios (ValidationMaster only - that group a number of programs together), or the system wide Enterprise view (ValidationMaster only)

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipWorkspaceHome
data.value: A "one-stop shop" for understanding the overall status of the current workspace, with comprehensive, easily digestible (and customizable) information. Access it by clicking the large workspace icon in the navigation bar

data.name: Onboarding_WelcomeToProduct
data.comment: {0} to be replaced with product name

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipAdministration
data.value: Powerful administration controls let those with sufficient access make changes to relevant workspaces, as well as managing users, notifications, system and security setttings, data syncs with external services, and more.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipUserProfile
data.value: Manage your user profile and settings (including passwords and localization). From this menu you can also access links to documentation about the page you are on, look at mini tutorials or keyboard shortcuts, or log out of the application.

data.name: Onboarding_SelectATour
data.value: Please choose an option below to see that tour

data.name: Onboarding_UpdateIntro_Message
data.value: Discover what's new in the latest update.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipRisk
data.value: Use risks to implement a full risk management solution for your products. Each risk can have a probability and an impact to help you analyze each risks exposure. Add risk mitigations to track how you are treating the risk

data.name: Onboarding_TourAims_AppIntro
data.value: This tour will help you navigate around the application. We are going to look at each part of the navigation bar - that dark section at the top of every page. Each part helps you move between the different areas of the application. If you hover over any of these parts a tooltip will give you more information.

data.name: GlobalNavigation_ColorScheme_AutoTitle
data.value: Color mode is handled by your operating system. Click to switch to dark mode

data.name: GlobalNavigation_ColorScheme_DarkTitle
data.value: A bold new look that's easier on the eyes. Click to switch to light (normal) mode

data.name: GlobalNavigation_ColorScheme_LightTitle
data.value: Classic, timeless dark text on light backgrounds. Click to switch to auto mode

data.name: Administration_Project_NeedToSelectTemplate
data.value: You need to select a template from the list!

data.name: MoreArtifactsThanCanDisplay
data.value: We're sorry, there are more artifacts in total than this view can display.

data.name: FileArtifactUploadDialog_FilenameRequired
data.value: You need to select or drop a file before attempting to Upload!

data.name: Global_ChooseFilterToUpdate
data.value: Choose the existing filter to update:

data.name: Global_IncludeColumns
data.value: Save the column selection with the filter.

data.name: Global_UpdateExistingOrSaveNew
data.value: Do you want to update an existing saved filter or save a new one?

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipEnterprise
data.value: The enterprise page gives a bird's-eye view across everything in your organization. Here you can see across all the portfolios in your organization.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_PortfolioRelativeSize
data.value: This chart shows the number of active requirements in each active portfolio. Hovering over a segment will show its percentage of all requirements (this is visually represented by the size of the donut wedge). Please note, portfolios with no active requirements are not shown.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_ProductRelativeSize
data.value: This chart shows the number of active requirements in each active product. Hovering over a segment will show its percentage of all requirements (this is visually represented by the size of the donut wedge). Please note, products with no active requirements are not shown.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_ProgramRelativeSize
data.value: This chart shows the number of active requirements in each active program. Hovering over a segment will show its percentage of all requirements (this is visually represented by the size of the donut wedge). Please note, programs with no active requirements are not shown.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_ReleaseRelativeSize
data.value: This chart shows the number of active requirements in each active release. Hovering over a segment will show its percentage of all requirements (this is visually represented by the size of the donut wedge). Please note, releases with no active requirements are not shown.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_EnterpriseOverallCompletion
data.value: This chart shows the proportion of all active requirements that have been completed across all active portfolios in your enterprise. When 100% of the requirements are completed, the color changes so that it is easy to tell what is in progress vs completed.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_PortfolioOverallCompletion
data.value: This chart shows the proportion of all active requirements that have been completed across all active programs in this portfolio. When 100% of the requirements are completed, the color changes so that it is easy to tell what is in progress vs completed.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_ProductOverallCompletion
data.value: This chart shows the proportion of all active requirements that have been completed across all active releases in this product. When 100% of the requirements are completed, the color changes so that it is easy to tell what is in progress vs completed.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_ProgramOverallCompletion
data.value: This chart shows the proportion of all active requirements that have been completed across all active products in this program. When 100% of the requirements are completed, the color changes so that it is easy to tell what is in progress vs completed.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_EnterpriseSchedule
data.value: This Gantt chart shows all active portfolios, programs, products, releases, and sprints in the enterprise. Each bar spans from the item's start date to end date. The darker shaded portion of each bar tells you how complete its requirements are.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_EnterpriseWorkspaceCompletion
data.value: This chart shows the progress of each portfolio in the enterprise. The left-hand chart shows progress from the start to end date of the portfolio. The bar's color indicates how on track the schedule is against requirement completion. The right-hand chart shows the proportion of requirements across active workspaces in the portfolio that have been completed.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_PortfolioSchedule
data.value: This Gantt chart shows all active programs, products, releases, and sprints in this portfolio. Each bar spans from the item's start date to end date. The darker shaded portion of each bar tells you how complete its requirements are.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_PortfolioWorkspaceCompletion
data.value: This chart shows the progress of each program in this portfolio. The left-hand chart shows progress from the start to end date of the program. The bar's color indicates how on track the schedule is against requirement completion. The right-hand chart shows the proportion of requirements across active workspaces in the program that have been completed.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_ProductSchedule
data.value: This Gantt chart shows all active releases and sprints in this product. Each bar spans from the item's start date to end date. The darker shaded portion of each bar tells you how complete its requirements are.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_ProductWorkspaceCompletion
data.value: This chart shows the progress of each active release with requirements attached in this product. The left-hand chart shows progress from the start to end date of the release. The bar's color indicates how on track the schedule is against requirement completion. The right-hand chart shows the proportion of requirements in the release that have been completed.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_ProgramSchedule
data.value: This Gantt chart shows all active products, releases, and sprints in this program. Each bar spans from the item's start date to end date. The darker shaded portion of each bar tells you how complete its requirements are.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_ProgramWorkspaceCompletion
data.value: This chart shows the progress of each product in this program. The left-hand chart shows progress from the start to end date of the product. The bar's color indicates how on track the schedule is against requirement completion. The right-hand chart shows the proportion of requirements across active releases in the product that have been completed.

data.name: Admin_UserDetailsEdit_LdapDnRequired
data.value: You need to enter a value for the new LDAP DN!

data.name: ListPage_ExportToReport_MaxLengthExceeded
data.value: You have selected too many artifacts to export. Please select fewer than {0} and try again.
data.comment: {0} the number of artifacts the system guesses should be appropriate

data.name: TestRun_ExistingPendingForUseAndTestId
data.value: You have pending test runs for the chosen test

data.name: TestRun_ExistingPendingForUseAndTestId_info
data.value: You can: run a test case from the beginning (start a new test run); or pick a recent pending test run. To see all of your pending test runs, navigate to the My Page.

data.name: Global_NoDataToDisplay
data.value: Sorry, there is no data to display

data.name: Dashboards_Legend_AheadOfSchedule_Tooltip
data.value: The percentage of completed requirements is greater than the percentage of the schedule that has elapsed

data.name: Dashboards_Legend_BehindSchedule_Tooltip
data.value: The percentage of completed requirements is less than the percentage of the schedule that has elapsed

data.name: Dashboards_Legend_Completed_Tooltip
data.value: All requirements included against the release / in releases in this workspace are complete

data.name: Dashboards_Legend_Late_Tooltip
data.value: The workspace or any of its children (if relevant) is running late. For a workspace itself to be late, its requirements are not yet all complete, but its end date has already passed

data.name: Dashboards_Legend_OnSchedule_Tooltip
data.value: The percentage of completed requirements is broadly the same as the percentage of the schedule that has elapsed

data.name: SystemInfo_DeleteSampleDataConfirm
data.value: Do you really want to delete all sample data? This will attempt to delete all sample products, programs (except the default), portfolios, and users. Please note that the root administrator (with username "adminstrator" and an ID of "1") will not be deleted.

data.name: InAppHelp_Chart_Program_ProjectTestSummary
data.value: This table shows each product in the program, together with the number of test cases, tests executed (runs), and the proportion of tests that have passed, failed, blocked, caution or not run. In addition, for each product it also shows the number of open incidents and the priority distribution of them.

data.name: TestCaseExecution_ActualResultNeeded
data.value: You need to enter the Actual Result to record this Test Step! Enter the result, then click the button below to confirm.

data.name: TestCaseExecution_ActualResultNeededPassAll
data.value: You need to enter an Actual Result for EVERY test step before you can Pass All. Please review all steps, add any missing actual results, then try to Pass All again.

data.name: TestCaseExecution_IncidentEntryInvalid
data.value: Please fill in all required field (including the Name) to add this incident

data.name: PlanningGrid_Available_HoursTooltip
data.value: Available hours is the same as the Planned Effort value for this release

data.name: PlanningGrid_Available_PointsTooltip
data.value: Available points is the same as the Planned Points for this release

data.name: PlanningGrid_Remaining_HoursTooltip
data.value: Remaining hours is calculated as available minus utilized hours

data.name: PlanningGrid_Remaining_PointsTooltip
data.value: Remaining points is calculated as available minus utilized points

data.name: PlanningGrid_Utilized_HoursTooltip
data.value: Utilized hours is the same as the Projected Effort value for this release

data.name: PlanningGrid_Utilized_PointsTooltip
data.value: Utilized points is the same as the Requirement Points value for this release

data.name: SourceCode_NoDifferenceBetweenRevisions
data.value: There are no differences to display

data.name: Documents_FilenameRequired
data.value: You need to specify a filename for this document!

data.name: SourceCode_Diff_CollapseTooltip
data.value: Collapse the view to only show the lines that have changed

data.name: SourceCode_Diff_ExpandTooltip
data.value: Expand the view to show all lines of the file

data.name: TestSetDetails_ParamatersNoneToAdd
data.value: There are no parameters you can add to this test set

data.name: GlobalNavigation_TooltipPullRequest
data.value: Manage and view all current pull request tasks. Use pull requests to structure your code review processes, so that only approved code can be merged into your build pipelines.

data.name: PullRequests_DestBranchNeeded
data.value: You need to choose the branch being merged TO!

data.name: PullRequests_DifferentBranchesNeeded
data.value: You need to choose different FROM and TO branches!

data.name: PullRequests_NameNeeded
data.value: You need to provide a Pull Request name!

data.name: PullRequests_SourceBranchNeeded
data.value: You need to choose the branch being merged FROM!

data.name: Global_SelectUserFromList
data.value: You need to select a user from the list!

data.name: FormValidation_FillInRequiredFields
data.value: Please fill in all required fields

data.name: AjxFormManager_UnsavedChanges
data.value: You have unsaved changes. Are you sure you want to continue?

data.name: RequirementDocument_NoRequirements
data.value: There are no requirements to show

data.name: HierarchicalDocument_ErrorsInFieldsNotVisible
data.value: Some of these fields are not visible on this page. You need to go to the details page of this artifact to make the required changes.

data.name: DiagramEditor_EmptyState
data.value: Select a shape or a connector
